title: 108_hr914
content: The Act titled "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income according to an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude space-related income from gross income. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalty amounts related to production or service. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income. Exceptions include telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages are also exempt. Proportional allocation between space-based and earth-based activities is required for products or articles. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income. Proportional allocation is required for products or articles produced partly in space. Products manufactured in outer space are excluded from tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal excises, imposts, duties, and tariffs if produced at a facility owned by U.S. persons. Benefits are phased out gradually after 2012 based on the number of years since 2013. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from certain taxes and introduces a credit for purchasing qualified space company stock. Effective after December 31, 2003, the amendments apply to taxable years. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" introduces a space company investment credit for purchasing qualified stock in a qualified space company. A qualified space company is a domestic C corporation with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000, and more than 70 percent of gross receipts derived from space-based business. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" introduces a space company investment credit for purchasing qualified stock in a qualified space company. Qualified stock is defined as any stock in a domestic C corporation meeting specific criteria, including being acquired at its original issue in exchange for money or other property. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" introduces a space company investment credit for purchasing qualified stock in a qualified space company. Qualified stock must be acquired at its original issue in exchange for money or other property. The stock must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) and the corporation must be a C corporation. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" introduces a space company investment credit for purchasing qualified stock in a qualified space company. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply for certain purchases by a corporation of its own stock. If the issuer of the qualified stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of purchase, the tax for that year will be increased by the decrease in credits allowed under section 38. This section does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" introduces a space company investment credit under section 45G(a). Amendments are made to sections 39(d) and 196 of the Code to restrict carryback of the credit before January 1, 2004. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" introduces a space company investment credit under section 45G(a) and amends the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to costs incurred after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a new section is added for the exclusion of gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. Gross income excludes gain from selling stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space with 90% of expenses related to this business. The term "qualified space corporation" is defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space with 90% of expenses related to this business. It does not include a corporation providing a service, product, or article described in section 140(b)(2). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003.
